questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Corinthians 1:1-18 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between human wisdom and God's foolishness.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'I' in the first sentence (v.1) and the phrase 'divisions' in v.12
Pay attention to the phrase 'the word of the cross' (v.18) as a key term

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Paul) does WHAT (writes to the church in Corinth) WHERE (the church at Corinth) and WHY (to address divisions and emphasize Christ's cross).
tips: Paul's apostolic authority is mentioned (v.1)
The divisions in the church are described (v.12-13)
The cross as the power of God (v.18)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Paul's declaration that Christ is the wisdom of God (v.20), the phrase 'foolishness of God' (v.20), or the statement about Christ being the power of God (v.24).
tips: The contrast between human wisdom and God's foolishness is profound and applicable to modern life
The phrase 'the word of the cross' (v.18) is a key term that shows the power of Christ's death
The declaration that Christ is our righteousness, sanctification, and redemption (v.30) is a powerful summary

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the church in Corinth through this passage?
tips: Paul is addressing the divisions in the church by emphasizing that Christ, not human leaders, is the source of unity and authority
The main point is that God's wisdom and power are found in the cross of Christ, not in human wisdom or status
This passage challenges the Corinthians to stop following human leaders and instead follow Christ alone

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'divisions', the concept of 'foolishness of God', and the role of the cross in salvation.
tips: 'Divisions' in the church context refers to factions following different leaders (Paul, Apollos, etc.)
The term 'foolishness of God' (Greek: logismos) means that God's ways are contrary to human understanding but are actually wise
The cross is the means by which God reconciles us to Himself, and it is the power that saves

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: In light of 1:18, what practical step can you take this week to avoid division and focus on Christ?
tips: Identify one area where you might be following human leaders or wisdom instead of Christ
Pray for unity in the church and for a heart that seeks Christ rather than human status
Share the gospel with someone who is divided by leaders

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God that He is the source of unity and wisdom through Christ. Ask for help to avoid division and follow Christ.
tips: Thank God for the cross as the power of salvation
Pray for courage to reject human wisdom and follow Christ
Ask God to unite the church in love and truth

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Corinthians 2:1-16 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between Paul's humility and the revelation of God's wisdom.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'I came not with' (v.1) and 'I was with them in weakness' (v.3)
Pay attention to the phrase 'what no eye has seen, nor ear heard, nor the heart of man imagined' (v.9)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Paul) does WHAT (teaches the Corinthians about God's wisdom), WHERE (the church in Corinth), and WHY (to correct their focus from human wisdom to Christ's cross).
tips: Include Paul's decision to know nothing but Jesus Christ and His crucified (v.2)
Note the contrast between the 'wisdom of God' (v.6-7) and the 'wisdom of men' (v.1)
Describe how the Spirit reveals the mystery of God (v.7)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Paul's humility (v.3), the mystery of God's wisdom (v.7), or the mind of Christ (v.16)?
tips: Paul's admission of weakness and fear shows his dependence on the Spirit (v.3)
The phrase 'what no eye has seen...' (v.9) is a profound revelation of God's plan
The mind of Christ (v.16) is the ultimate goal of the Spirit's work

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the church in Corinth through this passage?
tips: Paul is correcting the Corinthians who were focused on human wisdom and eloquent speech (v.1)
He emphasizes that true wisdom comes from the Spirit and the cross, not from human efforts (v.2-3)
The mystery of God's wisdom is revealed through the Spirit for believers (v.7)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The contrast between 'wisdom of God' and 'wisdom of men', the mystery of God's wisdom, or the role of the Spirit?
tips: The 'mystery' (v.7) refers to the hidden truth of Christ's crucifixion that God revealed to Paul through the Spirit
The 'wisdom of God' is not the same as the 'wisdom of men' (v.1) because it is from God and not human effort
The phrase 'the natural person does not accept the things of the Spirit' (v.14) highlights the need for spiritual insight

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of the Spirit revealing God's wisdom to your life this week?
tips: When you face a situation that seems confusing or beyond your understanding, ask the Spirit to reveal God's wisdom (v.9-10)
Surrender your reliance on human wisdom and focus on Christ crucified (v.2)
Pray for the mind of Christ (v.16) to help you see God's perspective in your challenges

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the Spirit revealing God's wisdom. Thank God for His revelation and ask for His guidance.
tips: Thank God for revealing the mystery of His wisdom through the Spirit
Pray for the courage to trust the Spirit's revelation in difficult circumstances
Ask God to help you understand the mind of Christ (v.16)

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Corinthians 3:1-17 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between human effort and God's growth.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'God's fellow workers' (v.5) and the foundation metaphor (v.10-11)
Pay attention to the contrast in verses 6-7: human effort vs. God's growth

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is being called to work, WHAT they are doing, WHERE it takes place (the church), and WHY (to build God's temple).
tips: The church in Corinth is described as infants in Christ (v.1)
Paul and Apollos are servants through whom the Corinthians believed (v.2-4)
The danger of building on a foundation of human effort (v.10-11)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the foundation being Christ (v.10-11), the fire test (v.13-15), or the warning about destruction (v.17).
tips: The phrase 'you are God's field and God's building' (v.9) shows the church as a living structure
The fire test (v.13) is a metaphor for God's judgment on false work
The warning that 'if anyone destroys God's temple, God will destroy him' (v.17) is a call to humility

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the church in Corinth about their role as God's fellow workers?
tips: Paul warns the Corinthians that they are not yet mature (infants) and that they are building on a foundation that is Christ alone
He emphasizes that human effort (like Paul and Apollos) is temporary, but God's growth is eternal
The main point is that the church is God's temple, and only God gives the growth; human effort is secondary

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The role of the foundation, the fire test, and the warning about destruction.
tips: The foundation is Christ (v.10-11) – not the church itself but Jesus as the only foundation
The fire test (v.13) is a metaphor for God's judgment on the work of the church, not a literal fire
The phrase 'God's temple' (v.16) refers to the church as the dwelling place of the Holy Spirit, not a physical building

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply this to your life this week? Consider your role as a 'fellow worker' in building God's church.
tips: Identify one area where you are building with wood, hay, or straw (unstable) and ask God to help you build with gold, silver, or precious stones (stable)
Pray for the Holy Spirit to help you build on the foundation of Christ (v.10-11) rather than on your own efforts
Reflect on the warning: if you destroy God's temple, God will destroy you (v.17) – what is your responsibility in the church?

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for Christ as the only foundation and ask for the courage to build with stable materials.
tips: Thank God for Christ as the only foundation
Ask for the courage to build with gold, silver, or precious stones (stable) rather than wood, hay, or straw (unstable)
Pray that the Holy Spirit will help you discern what is truly God's work

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Take turns reading 1 Corinthians 4 aloud together.
tips: Read slowly and clearly
Pause if something strikes you

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize what this passage is about.
tips: Keep it brief
Capture the main flow

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What stood out to you the most? What's the 'best bit'?
tips: Share what personally resonated
Listen to your partner

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What is the main point or central message of this passage?
tips: Think about the author's intent
Look for the big idea

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What difficulties or questions do you have about this passage?
tips: It's okay not to understand everything
Share honestly

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: What will you do about it? How will you apply this to your life?
tips: Be specific and practical
Think about this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about what you've learned and your applications.
tips: Thank God for what you learned
Pray for each other

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Corinthians 5:1-13 aloud, focusing on the description of the sin, the church's response, and the metaphor of leaven.
tips: Notice the shocking statement: 'a man has his father's wife' (v.1)
Pay attention to the phrase 'little leaven leavens the whole lump' (v.6)
The repeated phrase 'unleavened bread' (v.7) symbolizes purity

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO the church in Corinth is dealing with, WHAT they must do, WHERE and WHEN this happens, and WHY it matters.
tips: The sin: a man committing incest (v.1)
The church's response: remove the offender from the community (v.13)
The context: Paul's presence in spirit and the Passover connection (v.7)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the metaphor of leaven (v.6), the Passover connection (v.7), or the call to purge the evil (v.13)?
tips: The metaphor of leaven is powerful because it shows how one sin can corrupt the entire church community
The Passover connection (Christ as the lamb) reminds us that the church's purity comes from Christ's sacrifice
The phrase 'cleanse out the old leaven' (v.7) is a call to active removal of sin, not passive waiting

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the church in Corinth about church discipline and purity?
tips: The church must discipline serious sin to maintain its purity and avoid being corrupted by sin
This discipline is a sign of the church's maturity and obedience to Christ
The goal is the spiritual salvation of the sinner (v.5)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The severity of the sin, the process of church discipline, or the concept of 'spirit' being saved?
tips: The phrase 'a man has his father's wife' (v.1) is a severe sin that the church was dealing with, but it's not the only sin that requires discipline
Church discipline in the early church was a process of removal from the community, not excommunication as we understand it today
The phrase 'spirit may be saved' (v.5) refers to the eternal part of the person, so the goal is salvation through Christ, not punishment

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the call to 'cleanse out the old leaven' in your own life this week?
tips: Identify one area of sin or ungodliness in your life that needs to be addressed
Take a step to confess and remove that sin, just as the church cleanses the leaven
Ask God for the strength to be a 'new lump' (unleavened) in your life

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the theme of church discipline and purification.
tips: Thank God for the church's role in disciplining sin and keeping the church pure
Ask for the courage to confront sin in your life and in the church community
Pray that the church will be a 'new lump' (unleavened) in the spirit of Christ

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Corinthians 6:1-11 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between lawsuits and the body.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'do they not know' (v. 2, 6) to emphasize the church's ignorance
Pay attention to the phrase 'bought with a price' (v. 20) and 'temple of the Holy Spirit' (v. 19) in the body section
The list of sins (v. 9-10) is critical for understanding exclusion

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is involved, WHAT the church is doing, WHERE it's happening, and WHY Paul is concerned.
tips: The church in Corinth is bringing lawsuits against each other
Paul warns that the saints will judge the world and angels, so they are incompetent to handle trivial cases
The church has been washed, sanctified, and justified, but some are living in sin

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the lawsuit issue (v. 1-8), the list of sins (v. 9-10), or the body as a temple (v. 19-20)?
tips: The phrase 'your body is a temple of the Holy Spirit' (v. 19) is profound because it connects physical bodies to the presence of God
'You were bought with a price' (v. 20) emphasizes that we belong to God, not to ourselves
The list of sins (v. 9-10) shows the high standard of holiness in the church

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the church in Corinth through this passage?
tips: Paul is warning against lawsuits because they show a lack of love and unity in the church
He emphasizes that believers are not their own but bought by Christ, so they should live in harmony and respect each other
This passage shows that the church is called to be a community of saints who are united in Christ and not divided by lawsuits

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The lawsuit issue, the list of sins, or the concept of the body as a temple?
tips: The phrase 'the saints will judge the world' (v. 2) might seem odd because the saints are in a small church, but Paul means they are called to be holy and have authority in the world through Christ
The list of sins in v. 9-10 is specific and might be hard to apply to modern contexts
The concept of the body as a temple (v. 19) is a theological idea that the physical body is sacred because it houses the Holy Spirit

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: This week, how can you apply the idea that your body is a temple of the Holy Spirit to avoid lawsuits and conflicts with others?
tips: When you have a dispute, remember that your body is a temple and you belong to God, not to yourself
Ask God for wisdom to resolve conflicts without lawsuits
Choose to forgive and reconcile rather than bringing the issue to court

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the theme of the body and the kingdom. Thank God for the new identity in Christ and ask for strength to live in harmony.
tips: Thank God that you were bought with a price (Christ's blood) and are now His temple
Pray for the church in Corinth to stop lawsuits and live in unity
Ask God to help you honor your body as a temple and avoid sin

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Corinthians 7:1-40 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between Paul's concessions (v1-4) and his call to remain in the condition of calling (v29-31).
tips: Notice the phrase 'it is good for a man not to have sexual relations with a woman' in verse 1
Pay attention to the repetition of 'the appointed time has grown very short' in verse 29
Look for the phrase 'do not deprive one another' in verse 4

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO Paul addresses, WHAT he says about marriage and singleness, WHERE this occurs (the church in Corinth), and WHY he writes this (to address the present distress and encourage the church).
tips: Include the advice for the unmarried and widows (verses 25-28)
Note the condition for marriage (verses 28-31)
Describe the urgency of the 'appointed time' (verse 29)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the phrase 'it is good for a man not to have sexual relations with a woman' (v1), the 'appointed time has grown very short' (v29), or 'if you marry, you have not sinned' (v28)?
tips: The phrase 'appointed time has grown very short' (v29) highlights the urgency of spiritual maturity in this fleeting life
The contrast between 'it is good for a man not to have sexual relations with a woman' (v1) and the concession that marriage is acceptable (v2) shows Paul's careful balance
The phrase 'if you marry, you have not sinned' (v28) reassures those who are tempted to marry that they are not guilty

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the church in Corinth about the gift of marriage and singleness?
tips: Paul emphasizes that both marriage and singleness are gifts from God for serving Christ (v29-31)
He calls the church to remain in the condition they were called (v29-31) to avoid worldly troubles
The main point is that the church must live in the context of the present distress and the short time they have

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The phrase 'it is good for a man not to have sexual relations with a woman' (v1), the exception for an unbelieving partner (v12), or the meaning of 'the appointed time has grown very short' (v29)?
tips: 'It is good for a man not to have sexual relations with a woman' (v1) is a concession, not a command, meaning Paul is addressing the current situation of temptation without demanding total abstinence
The exception for an unbelieving partner (v12) shows that Paul does not want the church to cause division but to seek peace
'The appointed time has grown very short' (v29) refers to the limited time we have to live for Christ in this present age

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of the 'appointed time' (v29) this week?
tips: Identify one area where you are holding back from your spiritual calling (e.g., marriage or singleness) and ask God to help you remain in the condition you were called
Consider how you can live in the 'appointed time' by focusing on what truly matters (e.g., serving Christ) rather than worldly concerns
Pray for the strength to avoid the 'worldly troubles' that come with marriage (v32)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the gift of marriage or singleness He has given you to serve Him. Ask for the strength to remain in the condition you were called and to live in the appointed time.
tips: Thank God for the gift of marriage or singleness that He has given you to serve Him
Pray for the courage to remain in the condition you were called (v29-31) even when it's difficult
Ask God to help you avoid the worldly troubles that come with marriage (v32)

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Corinthians 8:1-13 aloud, focusing on the contrast between knowledge and love in verses 1-2 and the practical warning in verses 12-13.
tips: Notice the phrase 'knowledge puffs up, but love builds up' (v.1)
Pay attention to the repeated phrase 'stumbling block' in v.12
Note the decisive statement in v.13: 'if food makes my brother stumble, Paul will never eat meat'

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Paul and the Corinthian church), WHAT (the issue of eating food offered to idols), WHERE (the church in Corinth), and WHY (to avoid causing stumbling and honor Christ).
tips: Paul's warning that knowledge puffs up but love builds up (v.1)
The risk of causing the weak brother to stumble (v.12)
Paul's commitment to not eat meat that might cause his brother to stumble (v.13)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out? Consider the contrast between knowledge and love (v.1), the practical example of causing stumbling (v.12), or the final commitment (v.13).
tips: The phrase 'knowledge puffs up, but love builds up' (v.1) - clear contrast setting the stage
The question in v.12: 'will not his conscience be encouraged to eat food offered to idols?' - practical consequences
The decisive statement in v.13: 'if food makes my brother stumble, Paul will never eat meat' - priority of love

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the church in Corinth?
tips: Paul emphasizes that love for the weak brother (for whom Christ died) takes precedence over knowledge and right to eat (v.13)
This passage highlights the cost of Christian fellowship and the priority of love over self-interest

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? (2-3)
tips: The term 'food offered to idols' in ancient Corinthian context (v.1)
The term 'conscience' meaning inner sense of right and wrong (v.7)
The term 'stumbling block' meaning something causing sin (v.12)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How might you apply the theme of love over knowledge in your daily life?
tips: Consider an area where you have knowledge but are not acting in love (v.1)
Ask: 'If my action makes someone else stumble, will I change my behavior?' (v.13)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray specifically about the theme of love over knowledge.
tips: Thank God for Paul's example of sacrificing right to eat for love
Pray for strength to avoid causing others to stumble
Ask the Holy Spirit to help you see the brother for whom Christ died

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Corinthians 9:1-10 aloud, paying attention to the rhetorical questions and the contrast between Paul's rights and his self-sacrifice.
tips: Notice the repeated rhetorical questions: 'Am I not free? Am I not an apostle?'
Pay attention to the phrase 'the Lord commanded' (v. 12) and the contrast with Paul's refusal to use his rights (v. 13)
The phrase 'all things to all people' (v. 20) is a key concept

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Paul) does WHAT (argues for his rights as an apostle but then gives up those rights) in the church in Corinth, WHY (to preach the gospel without being hindered, but he chooses to give up his rights for the sake of the gospel).
tips: Include the fact that Paul is arguing his rights (to eat, drink, take a wife) but then says he has made no use of them
Note the context of the Corinthians questioning Paul's apostleship
The phrase 'the Lord commanded' (v. 12) shows that Paul's right to preach the gospel is not about personal gain

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Paul's rhetorical questions (v. 1-3), the phrase 'all things to all people' (v. 20), or the discipline of the body (v. 25).
tips: The rhetorical questions in verses 1-3 challenge assumptions about Paul's rights and apostleship
The phrase 'all things to all people' (v. 20) shows Paul's flexibility and love for the Corinthians
The discipline of the body (v. 25) is a strong image of self-control for the sake of the gospel

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the church in Corinth through this passage?
tips: Paul is defending his apostleship by showing he has the right to preach but chooses to forgo those rights
True apostleship is about self-sacrifice for the gospel rather than claiming rights

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The idea of Paul's rights as an apostle, the meaning of 'all things to all people', or the concept of disciplining the body for the gospel.
tips: 'The Lord commanded' (v. 12) refers to the gospel being the only way to support oneself, which might seem contradictory to having rights
The term 'all things to all people' (v. 20) shows adaptability but can be misunderstood as compromise
The discipline of the body (v. 25) is a metaphor for self-control that may be hard to apply today

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to a specific theme from the passage: 'Paul's sacrifice for the gospel' (v. 24-25). What can you do this week to follow Paul's example of self-discipline and sacrificial service?
tips: Consider an area where you are comfortable with your own rights (e.g., time, money) and how to give up some for the gospel
Think about how to 'discipline your body' by setting aside time for prayer or service

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray about Paul's example of sacrificial service and self-discipline.
tips: Ask God to help you see the cost of your own rights and to be willing to sacrifice for the gospel
Pray for the strength to discipline your body and mind for the sake of the gospel

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Corinthians 10:1-13 aloud, paying attention to the repeated phrases 'spiritual Rock', 'examples for us', and the warnings about idolatry and grumbling.
tips: Notice the phrase 'spiritual Rock' appears in verse 4 (the Rock is Christ)
Pay attention to the phrase 'twenty-three thousand fell in a single day' (verse 5) as a vivid example
The repetition of 'do not' in verses 6-8: 'Do not be idolaters... We must not indulge... We must not put Christ to the test... We must not grumble'

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize WHO (Israel and the church in Corinth) does WHAT (follows Christ, but some fail), WHERE (the wilderness for Israel, the church in Corinth), and WHY (to avoid repeating the same failures and live in unity).
tips: Include the 23,000 who died in one day (verse 5) as an example of the consequences of sin
Note that the spiritual Rock (Christ) is the same for all believers
The Lord's Supper (verses 16-17) is a participation in Christ's body and blood

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the spiritual Rock being Christ (verse 4), the 23,000 who died in one day (verse 5), or the Lord's Supper as participation in Christ (verses 16-17).
tips: The spiritual Rock that followed Israel was Christ (verse 4) - this is the central metaphor
The 23,000 died in one day (verse 5) - a shocking example of the consequences of sexual immorality
The Lord's Supper (verses 16-17) - 'one bread, one body' shows the unity of believers

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the church in Corinth through this passage about Israel's history?
tips: Paul warns the Corinthians to avoid the same failures as Israel (idolatry, sexual immorality, grumbling)
The key is that the spiritual Rock (Christ) is the same for all believers
The examples are for the church in Corinth to live in unity and obedience to Christ

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'spiritual Rock', the number 23,000, and the Lord's Supper as participation in Christ.
tips: 'Spiritual Rock' in verse 4 refers to Christ as the source of life and the one who provides water (the spiritual drink)
The 23,000 who died in one day (verse 5) is a historical account of the consequences of sexual immorality in the wilderness
The Lord's Supper (verses 16-17) is a participation in Christ's body and blood, which unites believers into one body

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the warning about grumbling (verse 10) this week?
tips: When you feel frustrated, ask: 'Am I grumbling like the Israelites?'
Choose to speak in a way that builds others up, not causes division
In your prayer, thank God for the spiritual Rock (Christ) that sustains you

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray about the warning against grumbling and the importance of unity in the church.
tips: Ask God to help you avoid grumbling and to be patient with others
Pray for the church in Corinth (and in your life) to be one body, as the Lord's Supper shows
Thank God for the spiritual Rock (Christ) that provides for us

chapters.chapterTitle: Head Coverings and the Lord's Supper

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Corinthians 11:1-34 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between the head coverings instructions and the Lord's Supper instructions.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'the head of' (v. 3, 7, 10) which emphasizes Christ as the head of every man
Pay attention to the contrast between the two main sections: verses 1-16 (head coverings) and verses 23-34 (Lord's Supper)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is being instructed, WHAT they are doing, WHERE it takes place (in the church), and WHY Paul is concerned.
tips: Include the church in Corinth as the audience
Note the two main issues: head coverings (verses 1-16) and the Lord's Supper (verses 23-34)
Highlight the problem of divisions in the church (v. 18-22) and the consequence of unworthy participation (v. 29)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Paul's teaching on head coverings (v. 3-10), the warning about the Lord's Supper (v. 23-29), or the call to examine oneself (v. 28-29)?
tips: The phrase 'the head of every man is Christ' (v. 3) is foundational to understanding the whole passage
The warning in verse 29: 'Whoever eats the bread or drinks the cup of the Lord in an unworthy manner...' is a powerful call to self-examination
The contrast in verse 23: 'For the Lord's Supper is a memorial of Christ's death' - this ties the ritual to Christ's sacrifice

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the church in Corinth through this passage?
tips: Paul is addressing the divisions and disorder in the church (v. 18-22) and the need for proper worship and unity
The head coverings issue is about the order of worship and the relationship between men and women in the church, which reflects the order of Christ and the church
The Lord's Supper instructions are a warning against taking the sacrament unworthily, which leads to spiritual harm

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The head coverings instruction for women, the meaning of 'unworthy manner', and the relationship between the head coverings and the Lord's Supper?
tips: In ancient Corinth, head coverings were a sign of respect and authority (for women) but Paul says the head of a woman is her husband (v. 3, 4) - so it's about the order of authority in the church
The term 'unworthy manner' (v. 29) refers to not having the right heart attitude, not just the physical act of eating
The Lord's Supper is a memorial of Christ's death (v. 23) but the church in Corinth was eating it in a disordered way, so Paul warns about the spiritual consequences

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply Paul's call to examine yourself in the Lord's Supper to your own worship this week?
tips: Before partaking in communion, ask: 'Am I in right relationship with Christ and the church?'
Consider the head coverings issue: How does your behavior reflect Christ's headship in the church?
In your small group or family, discuss the importance of unity and order in worship

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray about the need for unity and proper worship in the church, and the call to examine oneself in the Lord's Supper.
tips: Thank God for the Lord's Supper as a memorial of His sacrifice
Ask for the courage to examine yourself in worship and to live in unity with others
Pray for the church in Corinth (and us) to avoid divisions and unworthy participation

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Corinthians 12:1-13 aloud, paying attention to the repeated phrases 'one', 'many', and 'body'.
tips: Notice the phrase 'in one Spirit we were all baptized into one body' (v.13) appears as a key unity statement
Pay attention to the eye and hand analogy in verse 12: 'the eye cannot say to the hand, I have no need of you'
The repeated word 'one' emphasizes unity despite diversity

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the church in Corinth) is being taught, WHAT (the varieties of spiritual gifts and their unity), WHERE (the church community), and WHY (to prevent division and promote unity in the body of Christ).
tips: Include the concept of the church as 'one body' (v.12-13)
Note the diversity of gifts: prophecy, tongues, healing, etc. (v.7-11)
Describe how Paul emphasizes that all gifts come from the same Spirit and serve the body

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the body metaphor (v.12), the eye and hand analogy (v.12), or the unity in diversity of gifts (v.13)?
tips: The body metaphor: 'the body does not consist of one member but of many' shows that diversity is natural in God's design
The eye and hand example illustrates interdependence and mutual necessity in the body
The phrase 'in one Spirit we were all baptized into one body' (v.13) powerfully ties the spiritual reality to the church's unity

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the church in Corinth through this passage about spiritual gifts and the body of Christ?
tips: Paul aimed to correct the Corinthians' divisions by showing that the church is one body despite diverse gifts
The gifts are for the common good (v.7), not for individual glory
The unity of the body is a result of being baptized into Christ by the same Spirit (v.13)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The diversity of gifts, the meaning of 'baptized into one body', or the role of the church as the body of Christ?
tips: 'Spiritual gifts' can be confusing because they vary widely; Paul lists specific examples but does not define them all
'Baptized into one body' refers to spiritual union with Christ, not a physical ritual of baptism
The body metaphor might be hard to apply in modern contexts where the church is diverse in culture and belief

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the idea that every member of the church has a unique gift for the common good this week?
tips: Identify one gift you have or are called to use (e.g., listening, encouraging, serving) and share it with someone
Practice 'serving' by using your gift to build up others in the church this week
Ask the Holy Spirit to reveal how your gift can be used for the common good

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the unity of the body of Christ and ask for the Holy Spirit to empower us to use our gifts for His kingdom.
tips: Thank God for the diversity of gifts in the church and for the unity that comes from the Spirit
Pray for the courage to use your gifts without fear of judgment
Ask God to help us see how our gifts fit into the body of Christ

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Corinthians 13:1-13 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between spiritual gifts and love in verses 1-3.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'if' (three times) to contrast the gifts without love
Pay attention to the phrase 'love never ends' (v.8) and the contrast with the temporary nature of other gifts
The phrase 'the greatest of these is love' (v.13) is the climax of the passage

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Paul) is speaking about, WHAT (the nature of love compared to other spiritual gifts), WHERE (the church in Corinth), and WHY (to correct the church's focus on spiritual gifts and emphasize love).
tips: Include the three temporary gifts: prophecies, tongues, and knowledge (v.8)
Note that love is patient, kind, and never ends (v.4-8)
Paul's point: without love, even the greatest gifts are meaningless

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the contrast of love vs. other gifts (v.1-3), love's characteristics (v.4-8), or the conclusion (v.13)?
tips: The phrase 'love bears all things, believes all things, hopes all things, endures all things' (v.7) is comprehensive and deeply relational
The contrast in v.1-3: the temporary nature of gifts vs. the eternal nature of love
The phrase 'love never ends' (v.8) is a powerful promise of enduring love

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the church in Corinth through this passage?
tips: Paul is responding to the Corinthian church's overemphasis on spiritual gifts and wants them to prioritize love as the foundation of Christian life
Theological significance: Love reflects God's nature and is the unifying force in the church, making it the most important quality
The passage emphasizes that love is the only gift that remains forever (v.8-13)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The definition of love (v.4-8), the contrast between love and other gifts (v.1-3), or the idea that love never ends?
tips: The phrase 'love bears all things' (v.7) might be interpreted as love being passive, but in context, it means love has the strength to endure and forgive
The temporary nature of gifts (v.8-10) might be confusing because the church was experiencing spiritual gifts, but Paul is saying they are temporary compared to love
The phrase 'the greatest of these is love' (v.13) is a strong claim that love is the most important, which might be challenged by the Corinthians who were focused on the gifts

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of love that is patient and kind. What situation requires you to be patient and kind this week?
tips: Consider a conflict with a friend or family member where you need to show patience and kindness instead of reacting with anger
Practice 'bears all things' by forgiving and understanding others without holding grudges
Ask God for the strength to love others as Christ loved us

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God that love is the greatest and eternal gift. Ask for the strength to live out love in your daily life.
tips: Thank God for the gift of love that never ends
Pray for the courage to be patient and kind in difficult situations
Ask God to help you see others through the lens of love and to act accordingly

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Corinthians 14:1-20 aloud, focusing on the contrast between prophecy and tongues and the need for order in worship.
tips: Notice the phrase 'builds up' appears in verses 4 and 12
Pay attention to the contrast between 'speaks in a tongue' (v.2) and 'prophesies' (v.3)
The phrase 'God is not a God of confusion but of peace' (v.15) is a key statement

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize in your own words who is being addressed, what spiritual gifts are being discussed, where this occurs, and why Paul is emphasizing prophecy over tongues.
tips: Include that the church in Corinth was struggling with the use of tongues without interpretation
Note that Paul is writing to correct a problem of disorder in worship
Mention that the goal is to build up the church (v.4, 12)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the need for interpretation (v.13), the contrast between prophecy and tongues (v.2-3), or God's nature (v.15)?
tips: The command to have two or three prophets speak and have others weigh what is said (v.14) shows a practical solution to confusion
God being 'not a God of confusion but of peace' (v.15) is a powerful statement that defines the church's purpose
The contrast in verse 2: speaking in tongues is for God only, while prophecy is for the church

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the church in Corinth about the purpose and value of spiritual gifts, especially prophecy versus tongues?
tips: Paul's main goal is to have the church worship in a way that builds up the body (v.4, 12)
He is addressing a problem of disorder in their worship (v.13-14)
The spiritual gifts are for the church's benefit, not for individual glory

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts of this passage are challenging? Consider the definition of 'speaking in a tongue', the purpose of prophecy versus tongues, and the meaning of God's nature in this context.
tips: In ancient times, 'speaking in a tongue' could mean speaking in an unknown language (a language that no one understands) rather than a modern language
The phrase 'builds up' (v.4) means the gift of prophecy has a communal benefit, while tongues only benefits the individual
God being 'not a God of confusion' means that His plan is for order and unity, not for chaos

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the principle of 'building up the church' in your daily life this week? Consider what it means to speak in a way that benefits others.
tips: Think about a time when you could have spoken in a way that encouraged or built up someone else
Pray for the ability to speak in a way that is orderly and helpful in your relationships
Try to have one conversation this week where you focus on building up others rather than speaking in a way that is only for yourself

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for the church to be orderly in worship and for individuals to use their gifts to build up others.
tips: Ask God to help you understand when you are speaking in a way that is not building up others
Pray for the church to have more prophets (people who speak for encouragement) than those who speak in tongues without interpretation
Thank God that He is a God of peace and order

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Corinthians 15:1-20 aloud, focusing on the argument about the resurrection of Christ and the implications for the dead.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'according to the Scriptures' (v. 3, 4) and the emphasis on the resurrection being the firstfruits (v. 20)
Pay attention to the contrast between Adam and Christ (v. 45-49)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize who Paul is addressing, what he claims about Christ's resurrection, where this resurrection event occurred (in terms of the gospel), and why Paul is writing this passage.
tips: Include the key events: Christ's appearances (Cephas, the twelve, 500 at one time, James, apostles, Paul)
Note the consequence of no resurrection (preaching in vain, faith in vain, etc.)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: Which part of the passage stood out most? Consider: Christ as the firstfruits (v. 20), the Adam-Christ contrast (v. 45-49), or the declaration 'Death is swallowed up in victory' (v. 54)?
tips: The firstfruits metaphor shows that Christ's resurrection is the guarantee of our resurrection (v. 20)
The contrast between Adam (death) and Christ (life) highlights the reversal of death (v. 45-49)

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the church in Corinth through this passage about the resurrection of Christ?
tips: Paul is addressing the heresy that there is no resurrection of the dead (v. 12-19)
The theological significance: Christ's resurrection is the foundation of the gospel and the guarantee of our resurrection

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts of this passage are challenging? Consider the term 'firstfruits', the meaning of 'last Adam', or the statement about being changed at the last trumpet.
tips: In the Old Testament, 'firstfruits' refers to the first harvest offering; here, Christ is the first to be raised, guaranteeing our resurrection
'Last Adam' means Christ is the final and complete representative of humanity, the one who brings life (v. 49)
The 'change' at the last trumpet (v. 51) is a physical transformation from mortal to immortal, not a resurrection from the dead in the same sense

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the promise of Christ as the firstfruits to your life this week?
tips: When you face uncertainty about your future, remember that Christ has been raised and will bring life to all believers
Practice hope by focusing on the resurrection of Christ as the guarantee of your own resurrection

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray about the victory over death that Christ has won for us.
tips: Thank God for the resurrection of Christ, who has conquered death
Ask for the courage to face life's challenges knowing that death is swallowed up in victory
Pray for the hope that comes from Christ's resurrection

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Take turns reading 1 Corinthians 16 aloud together.
tips: Read slowly and clearly
Pause if something strikes you

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize what this passage is about.
tips: Keep it brief
Capture the main flow

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What stood out to you the most? What's the 'best bit'?
tips: Share what personally resonated
Listen to your partner

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What is the main point or central message of this passage?
tips: Think about the author's intent
Look for the big idea

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What difficulties or questions do you have about this passage?
tips: It's okay not to understand everything
Share honestly

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: What will you do about it? How will you apply this to your life?
tips: Be specific and practical
Think about this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about what you've learned and your applications.
tips: Thank God for what you learned
Pray for each other
